creator: t.lozina@verizon.net
text:
Performing a seemingly simple Test Plan involving HTTP Request is leading to a 
definite memory leak. As I allow the test plan to continue executing, the 
memory usage continues to pile up until Windows displays low memory alerts and 
finally JMeter starts to freeze up and crash. Note: No listeners are being used 
or anything else that may be accumulating data in this test plan.
Can you post a simple test case?
creator: sebb@apache.org
t.lozina@verizon.net
text: How do I post a file?

creator: sebb@apache.org
text:
There is a link on the Bugzilla page entitled "Create a new attachment" - just 
below the Keywords field.

creator: sebb@apache.org
text:
No test case yet provided, so reducing severity to normal.

Has anyone else got the same problem?

This bug appears to be related to garbage collection.  It is occurring with a developer that my team 
supports.

Putting the DOS command line window in the background, then clicking on it to bring it to the 
foreground, causes garbage collection to occur, and prevents a massive memory leak, which has 
been affecting JMeter's ability to run a complex test script.

This behavior occurs regardless of whether the graphical interface is enabled, or not.
creator: kdorsey@mit.edu
kdorsey@mit.edu
text:
The memory leak still occurs, causing threads to be dropped, even when the foreground / 
background workaround previously described is used.  It just happens more slowly.  More detailed 
bug report to follow.

creator: woolfel@yahoo.com
text:
no additional report was added. Since I've profiled jmeter in OptimizeIt over 2
dozen times for the monitor, distribution graph, and webservice sampler, I'm
pretty confident the issue is not JMeter. Without further details, it's hard to
figure the exact cause. the only thing I can think of which could cause memory
leak is if the user only has 128Mb of ram and the system is disk caching.

it is possible with heavy disk caching the heap gets fragmented and produces
results equivalent to a memory leak. I've also seen this type of behavior in
other VM environments like .NET. If that is the case, it is really a hardware
issue. If there isn't enough memory, there's not much a program can do.
especially VM environments.

This does not seem to be a problem in 2.0.2

Please re-open with details if the problem is still present
creator: sebb@apache.org
